docs.lead_paragraph: Bumper stickers here shout the slogan ''Slow down! This ain't the Mainland!'' But drivers are now in open revolt over a program forcing them to drive more slowly. This month the state began using digital cameras -- operated from unmarked vans and mounted near intersections -- to catch drivers who speed and run red lights on selected state roads and highways.

headline.main: Drivers in Hawaii Suffer From Camera Rage

docs.abstract: Hawaii drivers are in open revolt over state's use of digital cameras to catch those who speed and run red lights on selected state roads and highways; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: William E. Kirwan and Robert S. Schwartz each invited me last week to Columbus, Ohio, next fall to watch a college football game. Nothing like it in the world, they both said, separately. I'm psyched for the trip. Ever the diplomat, I will spend a half with each of them. They both love the game but have different takes on the people who administer it. Kirwan, the president of Ohio State University, says that his football players are ''students participating in extracurricular activities.'' While they could use another $2,000 a year to make ends meet, he says, they don't want the salaries or the unions that would mean ''the end of college athletics as we know it.'' Tall, handsome, square-jawed and crinkly around the eyes, Kirwan sounds presidential when he says that paying college athletes ''will never happen -- it's a nonstarter -- a bad idea.''

headline.main: BackTalk; In College Athletics, You Have to Follow the Money

docs.abstract: Robert Lipsyte article, second in series, examines role of money in college sports; Ohio State University president William E Kirwan discusses controversies over issue and suggests how to reform system; photo (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The news that Senator Edward M. Kennedy and President Bush are coming together to seek a deal on a federal patients' rights bill (news article, Jan. 23) is good news for the millions of H.M.O. patients who are left virtually powerless against their H.M.O.'s. What's also good news is that the most contentious point between the president and the senator, the right to sue, can be easily resolved. In California, I signed into law in 1999 an aggressive slate of 21 H.M.O. reforms, including a right to sue with no caps. At the same time, we established a comprehensive H.M.O. Help Center, staffed by doctors, patients' rights experts and customer service representatives, all available 24 hours a day to consumers with H.M.O. problems.
docs.abstract: Calif Gov Gray Davis letter holds news that Sen Edward M Kennedy and Pres Bush are coming together to seek deal on federal patients' bill of rights bill is good news for millions of HMO patients who are left virtually powerless against their HMO's; notes that California established right to sue in 1999, with no caps, and that state has not experienced increase in number of lawsuits against HMO's

docs.lead_paragraph: Americans perceive Republicans as far more entangled in the Enron debacle than Democrats, and their suspicions are growing that the Bush administration is hiding something or lying about its own dealings with the Enron Corporation before the company filed for bankruptcy protection, the latest New York Times/ CBS News Poll shows. Even among Republicans, a majority said they believed that the administration had not been forthcoming about its dealings with Enron. That perception could pose a threat to Republican candidates in the midterm elections this year, and undermine the White House drive to portray the Enron collapse as affecting Republicans and Democrats equally.

headline.main: Poll Finds Enron's Taint Clings More to G.O.P. Than Democrats

docs.abstract: New York Times/CBS News Poll shows Americans perceive Republicans as far more entangled in Enron scandal than Democrats, and their suspicion is growing that Bush administration is hiding something or lying about his own dealings with Enron before company filed for bankruptcy protection; that perception, even among majority of Republicans polled, could pose threat to Republican candidates in midterm elections, and undermine White House drive to portray Enron collapse as affecting Republicans and Democrats equally; Republican Congressional candidates begin midterm election year with albatross of being considered far more tied to Enron than their Democratic rivals; in last week alone, portion of people saying they are paying attention to Enron collapse has risen to three-fourths from two-thirds, and more people view it as Republican problem; graph (M)

byline.original: By RICHARD L. BERKE and JANET ELDER

docs.lead_paragraph: State Comptroller H. Carl McCall is charging that the Pataki administration limits access to birth control, sterilization and abortion for thousands of women in public health programs, a claim supported by abortion rights advocates. The charge stems from the state's practice of contracting with health maintenance organizations run by the Roman Catholic Church to care for people under programs like Medicaid, Child Health Plus and Family Health Plus. Those managed care companies do not provide certain services because they violate church teachings, so the public health programs allow recipients in such plans to go elsewhere for those services.

headline.main: McCall Is Critical of Pataki On Access to Birth Control

docs.abstract: New York State Comptroller H Carl McCall is charging that Pataki administration limits access to birth control, sterilization and abortion for thousands of women in public health programs; charge stems from state's practice of contracting with health maintenance organizations run by Roman Catholic Church to care for people under programs like Medicaid, Child Care Plus and Family Health Plus; those managed care companies do not provide certain services because they violate church teachings, so public health programs allow recipients in such plans to go elsewhere for those services; critics say that women often do not know when they enroll that their health maintenance organization does not provide those services, that they are often not told they can obtain those services elsewhere, and that finding outside provider needlessly burdens patients; administration insists that system works, and that it gives women information and health care choice they need; McCall, Democrat who is running for governor against incumbent Republican George E Pataki, plans to release report Jan 28 (M)
docs.snippet: State Comptroller H. Carl McCall is charging that the Pataki administration limits access to birth control, sterilization and abortion for thousands of women in public health programs, a claim supported by abortion rights advocates.    The charge...

docs.lead_paragraph: The nation's largest health insurers, which recruited elderly people to Medicare H.M.O.'s by dangling offers of free prescriptions, are eliminating drug coverage or demanding sharply higher payments for drugs and treatments from some of their sickest members. The companies say they are losing so much money providing drug coverage that they have to limit what they offer if they are to stay in the Medicare market. But the cutbacks effectively leave the companies providing insurance to their healthy members, while tens of thousands of elderly patients with serious diseases like cancer have no affordable insurance coverage for their basic medical needs.

headline.main: Many H.M.O.'s For the Elderly Cut or Abolish Drug Coverage

docs.abstract: Nation's largest health insurers, which recruited elderly people to Medicare Health Maintenance Organizations by dangling free prescriptions, are eliminating drug coverage or demanding sharply higher payments for drugs and treatments from some of their sickest members; companies say they are losing so much money providing drug coverage that they have to limit what they offer if they are to stay in Medicare market; Secure Horizons is raising co-payments for drugs in eight states where it operates; Kaiser Permanente has placed new ceilings on drug payments; Aetna US Healthcare eliminated drug coverage last year; Health Net, formerly PHS Health Plans, set $750 annual limit for drug costs for each member in Brooklyn and Queens this year, down from $1,000 in 2001 (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, and the White House are engaged in intensive discussions seeking a deal on patients' rights legislation, and their usual allies are expressing alarm at the terms of a possible compromise. The talks focus on the ability of patients to enforce their rights by suing health plans, insurance companies and employers who have promised various health benefits.

headline.main: Kennedy and Bush Negotiate on Patients' Rights, Alarming Their Allies

docs.abstract: Sen Edward M Kennedy and Bush administration seek deal on patients' rights bill, alarming their usual allies about terms of possible compromise; talks focus on ability of patients to sue health plans, insurance companies and employers who have promised various health benefits; consumer advocates press for stronger provisions of Senate-approved bill over more limited House-passed bill backed by Bush; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-7 22 Wounded in Jerusalem By Palestinian Gunman A Palestinian policeman on leave who was dressed as an Israeli soldier opened fire in Jerusalem's crowded shopping district, wounding 22 people before the police killed him. Earlier, in the West Bank, Israeli forces killed four militants in Nablus. A1 Aftermath of Attack in India Senior Indian officials suggested that a Pakistan-based Islamic group was behind the attack on an American diplomatic outpost in Calcutta that left four Indian police officers dead. But the F.B.I. director, Robert Mueller, who is visiting New Delhi, said it was too early to say who was responsible and whether it really was a terror attack on American interests. A6

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Tom Daschle, the Democratic majority leader, said today that he intended to begin the new legislative year with an effort to pass the elements of an economic recovery package that both parties support. Having been criticized by Republicans as obstructionist since a recession-fighting package died in the Senate last month, Mr. Daschle sought to recast the partisan debate over how to help the economy in terms favorable to his party.

headline.main: Daschle Hopes to Lead Senate Toward an Economic Recovery Package

docs.abstract: Sen Tom Daschle says he will open new legislative year with bid to pass economic recovery package elements backed by both parties; Republicans all but reject offer, saying they continue to push for broader package that includes permanent tax cuts; Daschle's office says his plan would cost $69 billion in current fiscal year and $7 billion next year; administration says Pres Bush's budget will call for spending rise of up to 9 percent and forecast deficit that could reach $100 billion; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Conseco Inc. said Thomas Kilian, the executive in charge of its life insurance and annuity businesses, is leaving the company as it consolidates to save money. Conseco is combining some of its life insurance, supplemental health insurance and annuities operations into a single unit, led by Liz Georgakopoulos, the company said.
